# Major Scale in A (Aeolian Mode)

## Presentation
The Major scale in A, also known as the Aeolian mode or natural minor scale, consists of the notes A, B, C, D, E, F, and G. This scale has a melancholic sound and is widely used in various musical genres like rock, blues, and jazz.

## Notes and Intervals
- A (Root)
- B (Major 2nd)
- C (Minor 3rd)
- D (Perfect 4th)
- E (Perfect 5th)
- F (Minor 6th)
- G (Minor 7th)

## Musical Flavor
The Major scale in A, when played in Aeolian mode, has a dark, somber, and emotive quality to it. It often evokes feelings of introspection, suspense, or melancholy. This scale is versatile and can be used to create both hauntingly beautiful melodies and intense harmonic progressions.

## Songs
1. **"Stairway to Heaven" by Led Zeppelin** - This iconic rock ballad features sections that highlight the emotive qualities of the Major scale in Aeolian mode.
  
2. **"All Along the Watchtower" by Jimi Hendrix** - The guitar solo in this classic rock song makes use of the Aeolian mode, adding a sense of tension and drama to the music.
  
3. **"So What" by Miles Davis** - This jazz standard showcases how the Major scale in Aeolian mode can be used in a more sophisticated harmonic context, creating a mood of contemplation and introspection.
